title: Feature Request: "Greyscale Unregistered Senders" Option
creator: selcukgokteki
content:
Dear Thunderbird Team,

I'm an active user of Thunderbird for my daily email management and greatly appreciate the flexibility your program offers. The ability to color-code emails from contacts in my address book has been incredibly helpful in organizing my inbox.

However, distinguishing and color-coding emails from senders not in my address book is quite cumbersome with the current filtering system. Manually creating "does not contain" rules for each individual address is impractical and requires constant updates.

At this point, I'd like to submit a feature request that would significantly enhance the user experience:

A one-click button or easily accessible setting, such as "Greyscale Unregistered Senders."

Having this feature directly integrated into the Thunderbird interface (for instance, within Inbox settings or under the Tools menu) would save a significant amount of time and offer great visual convenience, especially for users who receive a large volume of emails. Having emails from unregistered senders appear in greyscale or a similar neutral color would help in quickly identifying important emails while separating those from unknown senders.

I believe that integrating such a feature would further strengthen Thunderbird's user-friendly design and make email management even more intuitive.

Thank you for considering my request. I wish you continued success in your work.

Sincerely,

Selçuk Göktekin
metadata: ;useragent:Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/136.0.0.0 YaBrowser/25.6.0.0 Safari/537.36

title: Inbox has Red Grid vertical/horizontal lines on businesses only.
creator: rblank419
content:
Here we go again! Inbox has Red Grid vertical/horizontal lines on businesses only after Thunderbird update. This same issue happened back in April this year after Thunderbird update and Toad gave me the fix. It didn't work this time. Don't understand why a new release causes this problem. I've tried trouble shooting mode and it does the same think. HELP

Dell Inspiration 366B Ram 8GB 64-bit operating system Windows 10 V 22H2 Thunderbird 32-bit 128.13.0 release 7/24/2025 & 140.1.0 release on 7/26/25


      • Previous Issue***

Ray Blankenship 4/2/25, 10:45 AM more options The last couple days any emails from a business only have red horizontal/vertical grid lines. If it says to view or track package it won't let me, do it. If I drag that email over to another folder it acts normal and if I drag it back to my in box it has the red lines. I've checked the emails in the server, they are normal. Also, there is yellow bar at the bottom of the attached email. It acts like a message I'm trying to send because the to is prefilled out with my email address. Weird Dell Inspiration 366B Ram 8GB 64-bit operating system Windows 10 V 22H2 Thunderbird 32-bit 128.13.0 release 128.9.0 release 3/18/2025

Attached screenshots

I have this problem, too All Replies (1) Toad-Hall Toad-Hall Top 25 Contributor 4/5/25, 9:12 AM more options The 'Inbox' has somehow got itself set with a 'Drafts' flag. Please try this first and follow the instructions carefully.

In Folder Pane, select another folder - not Inbox

In 'Account Settings' Select 'Copies & Folders' for the problem account Scroll down to the 'Drafts and Templates' section Select 'Other' and choose 'Inbox for account' Then without exiting or doing anything, do this: Select 'Other' and select 'Drafts on account' Close 'Account Settings' tab Back in Folder Pane select 'Inbox'. Does it look correct ?

Helpful?
metadata: ;useragent:Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/138.0.0.0 Safari/537.36 Edg/138.0.0.0

content:

Since the update, I’m now getting notifications for every incoming email—including those that go directly to the Junk/Spam folder.

title: Deploying Thunderbird in a terminal server environment with some default settings preconfigured.
creator: twortman
content:
We've been running TB in our environment on terminal servers for the last 6-7 years. We have Group Policies configured to pre-configure several default settings (mail storage path, global calendars, mail server info (domain, type, ports etc) when the user first opens Thunderbird new. This has been working fine upto version 140. It no longer functions. We updated the ADMX/ADML files for the current release, with no change. When we go into look at the Group Policy settings, those options are o longer available.

It's been suggested that setting up a Policies.json file is what we need to do now, but those settings do not appear to be available. Is there any was to do what we were doing with the current version of TB, via Policies, or Group Policy that I'm missing?

Thanks in advance! Tim

title: Ghost Folders from Exchange Server
creator: jrodgers40
content:
Hello,

My work uses Office 365 for email, but I much prefer Thunderbird to Outlook, so I connect via IMAP. I am finding that dozens of folders I have deleted reappear in the Thunderbird folder list as italicized, and then when trash is emptied they persist in Deleted Items italicized as well.

I also use Google Workspace in Thunderbird and don't see this issue. I have set up new profiles from scratch on multiple machines on Windows, macOS, and Linux. The problem always returns.

My sense is that the italics represent old subscriptions to folders that no longer exist. The IMAP subscriptions are enumerated somewhere that is inaccurate and/or corrupt so that unsubscribing or deleting is ineffective (i.e. Thunderbird lists the folders that O 365 says are subscribed to, but O 365 can't delete folders that don't exist).

I have been in this job 29 years, which is to say I have a lot of mail, and a lot of folders, and a lot of folders that have been deleted when names of departments changed over that time or people retired. I am willing to accept that Microsoft's IMAP breaks when you have more than X folders or Y messages.

I started off asking our O 365 admins "I don't know how to do this, but is there a JSON or XML or something that lists IMAP subscriptions that can be deleted so I can start fresh?" They didn't know, so now we have taken up the issue with Microsoft. They insist the folders are not in the mail store, which I don't dispute. They have also suggested it's a Thunderbird issue. This makes no sense, since how Thunderbird wouldn't know when I set up a new profile, for example, that I once had a folder called Vendors with a sub-folder called Polycom, unless O 365 listed it.

I am ready to save all the email and ask the O 365 admins to create a new account for me, assuming that I had too many folders and broke my mail store in way that nobody seems to know how to fix. Microsoft suggested I post here first.

Is anybody here familiar enough with O 365's IMAP implementation to know how to reset a mail store's IMAP subscriptions?
metadata: ;useragent:Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:141.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/141.0

title: How to set up an IMAP email account in Thunderbird to receive and file emails on multiple computers
creator: ArtisanEW
content:
Our business email is technically a Gmail account that shows as our business name. (info@businessname.com) In past Gmail allowed us to set up emails on Thunderbird or other system as a POP account. As such the email would be set up as this..... recent:info@businessname.com This allowed us to receive emails on multiple computers where each person could file or delete as needed.

Gmail has since required us to only use IMAP accounts for security. In Thunderbird when you set up an IMAP account it will not let you put the word "recent" in front of the email name AND if someone deletes the email on one computer or phone it is then deleted on the others.

The oddest thing about this whole mess is one of our computers still has the POP account for one email (we have 4 emails) and three had to be set up as an IMAP.

Any suggestions on how to get around this issue?

Thanks in advance
metadata: ;useragent:Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:140.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/140.0
